awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Additive Manufacturing of Wear Resistant Metal-Composites for Biomedical Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
Metallic biomaterials are typically the choice for wear resistant parts in most biomedical devices towards load-bearing implants. However, concerns are growing related to metal ions in the body that can cause metallosis, and severe tissue and bone damage in some patients. Metallic devices offer greater motion, higher stability and higher than 99 percent reduction in wear debris compared to polymer components; however, use of these metallic implants dropped significantly in recent years primarily due to metal ion release concerns. This Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award supports fundamental research to gain understanding on metal-ceramic composites that can reduce the release of metal ions in human bodies due to in situ formation of self-lubricating films at the contact surface. Results from this research can offer future direction to solve long-standing metal ion release problems in load-bearing implants such as total hip arthroplasty and total knee arthroplasty, which can increase life of implants' for patients of all ages.  

In load-bearing implants, when two metal surfaces come in contact, there is wear induced damage that releases metal ions inside human bodies. The goal of this project is to minimize release of metal ions from metallic implants inside human bodies using self-lubricating ceramic based tribofilms. These films are formed in situ at the contact surfaces of metal-ceramic composites, and are similar to cartilage between the two hard articulating surfaces in load-bearing implants. The project will generate fundamental knowledge related to processing of metal-ceramic composites capable of forming self-lubricating films during articulation via laser based additive manufacturing. The research objective is to understand the influence of different amounts of calcium phosphates addition to titanium on mechanical and biological properties of titanium-calcium phosphate composites. To achieve this objective, first, titanium-calcium phosphate metal-ceramic composites will be processed using laser engineered net shaping with varying amounts of calcium phosphates, from 1 to 10 weight percent of titanium. Second, mechanical properties (such as tensile and compression strengths, and elastic moduli) of titanium-calcium phosphate composites will be measured under uniaxial loading using servo-hydraulic testing set-up. Third, wear resistance of these composites will be evaluated using flat-on-flat fully automated wear testing set-up. Finally, in vitro biological properties of these composites will be evaluated using human osteoblast cells at day 3, day 7 and day 11 in culture media.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Project Description: Load-bearing implants such as total hip arthroplasty (THA) and total knee arthroplasty (TKA) are among the most clinically successful interventions in health care. Among THA and TKAs, CoCrMo alloy is typically the choice of wear resistant alloy for most devices. However, concerns are growing related to Co and Cr ions in the body that can cause metallosis, and severe tissue and bone damage in some patients. This program was focused on fundamental understanding of the wear mechanisms due to in situ formation of soft tribofilms similar to cartilage between the two hard articulating surfaces for load-bearing implants to minimize wear induced damage and metal ion release. 

 

Specific Aim 1: To understand wear resistance and metal ion release of innovative CaP reinforced Ti6Al4V composites. 

Specific Aim 2: To educate and train graduate and undergraduate students.

 

Milestones: Following are the project specific milestones.

1.    Optimized processing parameters for uniformly distributed CaP reinforced Ti6Al4V.

Uniformly distributed CaP in Ti64 matrix composites were manufactured.

 2.    Tribofilm characterization under different test condition and compositions.

It has been shown that tribofilm formation occurs during articulation via in situ contact resistance measurements.

 3.    Interfacial damage evaluation under different loading conditions.

We have measured interfacial damage in coated samples.

 4.    In vitro cytotoxicity assessment.

We have shown that these samples are non-toxic. 

 5.    Measurement of metal ion release for optimum composite coatings.

Metal ion release was measured and shown that it decreased due to tribofilm formation.

 

Intellectual property: US Patent # 9,987,397 - Bose, S and Bandyopadhyay, A, (2018), Wear Resistant Low Friction Coefficient Surfaces for Joint and Bone Replacement Materials and Devices.

 

Key research results

Processing of Ti6Al4V-HA composites: Ti6Al4V and HA powders were purchased and used in our work. All powders in these experiments were premixed. The control samples consisted of pure Ti6Al4V. Composite samples containing 3 wt% HA, were ball milled and sieved at a mesh of -100/+325. All samples were built on 3mm thickness Ti6Al4V substrates. Laser power of 380 to 420W and a raster scan speed of 45-60 cm/min were used while depositing Ti6Al4V-HA composites along with a powder feed rate of 60g/min. For CoCrMo-HA composites, CoCrMo alloy powder was mixed with 0% and 3% (by weight) of HA powder prior to LENS using similar protocol. Laser power of 400W and a raster scan speed of 45-60 cm/min were used while depositing CoCrMo-CaP composites along with a powder feed rate of 60g/min on a Stainless Steel 410 substrate of 3mm thickness. Fig. 1a and b show microstructures of LENS processed Ti6Al4V and 3%HA-Ti6Al4V. Distinct Widmansttten patterns of a-Ti (hcp structure) with b-Ti (bcc structure) along the grain boundary can be seen. For HA added composite, uniform distribution of HA along the grain boundary can be seen as white crystals in Fig 1b.

 

Tribological characterization of Ti6Al4V-HA composites: Tribological data was collected using a single station fully automated Biotribometer. All tests were run using linear ball-on-disc reciprocating wear conforming to ASTM standard G133-05 (2010). All samples were tested with a normal load of 7N in fully immersed condition using deionized water at room temperature. All tests were run for 1000 meter distance, at a linear reciprocating speed of 1200mm/min for the entire duration of the test, forming wear tracks of length 10mm. The load and distance were used after confirming that steady-state wear regime can be established under these experimental conditions. Hardened chrome-steel balls of diameter 3mm were used to ensure electrical conductance through the samples during wear testing to measure in situ changes in contact resistance at the articulating surface. If there is formation of any tribofilm, due to the nonconducting nature of the film, the contact resistance should increase. Fig. 1c and d show scanning electron microscopy images of wear track of Ti6Al4V with and without HA. Extensive wear induced damage can be seen in Ti6Al4V surface (Fig. 2c), while the 3%HA surface shows a smooth coating layer (Fig. 2d). Fig. 1e shows the compound wear behavior. With increasing wear distance, wear rate is increasing in Ti6AL4V as expected from Fig. 2c due to extensive surface and subsurface damages. However, wear rates for the 3%HA samples dropped significantly after ~ 700m distance. This is interesting as the compound wear measured via the strain gage didn't see any new wear induced damage, which dropped the rate of wear. From Fig. 1f, around the same distance, contact resistance for the 3%HA sample increased to validate the concept that there is tribofilm formation at the contact surface. However, no change in contact resistance can be seen for the control Ti6Al4V samples. Combining the results of Figs. 2e and f, it is certain that the formation of tribofilm lowers the wear induced damage and overall wear rate of Ti alloy approaches commercial medical grade CoCrMo alloy.

 


Last Modified: 05/14/2020
Modified by: Amit Bandyopadhyay
